dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you're telling me, uh, over a third of all passenger planes globally are just, like, parked right now? What even is that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you're telling me, uh, over a third of all passenger planes globally are just, like, parked right now? What even is that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked, and scheduled flights this week will offer fewer than half as many total seats as in mid-January.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, that's, uh, that's over 8,500 planes, a third of those grounded. It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, that's, uh, that's over eight thousand, five hundred planes, a third of those grounded. It's pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Over a third of the global fleet of 8,500 passenger planes have been parked...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Grounded. Right. And they think it's gonna take five years for airlines to, like, get back to their former size? That's just, uh, insane, B.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Grounded. Right. And they think it's gonna take five years for airlines to, like, get back to their former size? That's just, uh, insane, B.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With thousands of older planes likely to be retired permanently, with a tilt toward widebodies, and delivery of new planes deferred or canceled as airlines seek to cut costs, Stallard believes the active airline fleet wont return to 2019 levels until about 2025.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's the projection from a lot of industry watchers. Especially with, you know, new virus strains being announced.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's the projection from a lot of industry watchers. Especially with, you know, new virus strains being announced.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the coronavirus pandemic ends, many industry watchers now expect it will take years for airlines to return to their former size.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Five years? But I just read, like, some analyst said 18 to 24 months to "some level of normal." Which one is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five years? But I just read, like, some analyst said eighteen to twenty four months to some level of normal. Which one is it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Cowen airline analyst Helane Becker told Forbes she expects it will take 18 to 24 months for traffic to return to some level of normal.

dialogue_turns.text: That was Helane Becker, from Cowen. She's talking "some normal," not full recovery to 2018 levels. Robert Stallard estimates that's 2027.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That was Helane Becker, from Cowen. She's talking some normal, not full recovery to twenty eighteen levels. Robert Stallard estimates that's twenty twenty seven.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...and a slow recovery that only sees airline traffic return to 2018 levels in 2026.

dialogue_turns.text: "Some normal." Okay. So, like, still flying half-empty planes then? And Boeing wants sixty billion dollars for this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Some normal. Okay. So, like, still flying half-empty planes then? And Boeing wants sixty billion dollars for this?

dialogue_turns.text: That's their ask for U.S. aerospace, yeah. There are even whispers about a potential merger with Lockheed Martin.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Boeing called for at least $60 billion in financial support for U.S. aerospace...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sixty billion. For an industry that, uh, needs fewer planes than they thought just a few months ago? Two thousand fewer, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sixty billion. For an industry that, uh, needs fewer planes than they thought just a few months ago? Two thousand fewer, actually.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Airlines will need 6,300 new aircraft over the next five years, estimates Robert Stallard, an analyst with Vertical Research Partners, about 2,000 fewer than hed forecast just a few months ago.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's a direct result of the, uh, 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year. Demand just cratered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a direct result of the, uh, forty percent reduction in airline passenger miles this year. Demand just cratered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats based on an estimate of a stomach-churning 40% reduction in airline passenger miles this year, roughly matching the industry group IATAs forecast...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So we're just going to, like, bail out these huge companies to keep making planes no one's flying? What's the actual point?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So we're just going to, like, bail out these huge companies to keep making planes no one's flying? What's the actual point?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's about preventing, you know, a full collapse. Keeping factories open, trying to maintain some level of employment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's about preventing, you know, a full collapse. Keeping factories open, trying to maintain some level of employment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Also likely a turnoff is language in the $2 trillion stimulus package that requires loan recipients to maintain headcount at 90% of current levels until Sept. 30.

dialogue_turns.text: "Full collapse." Right. And then Boeing's CEO is like, "Nope, not if I have to give up equity." Seriously? After all that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Full collapse. Right. And then Boeing's C E O is like, Nope, not if I have to give up equity. Seriously? After all that?

dialogue_turns.text: David Calhoun, yeah. He's, uh, pretty firm on that. The stimulus package also requires maintaining 90% headcount.

Also likely a turnoff is language in the $2 trillion stimulus package that requires loan recipients to maintain headcount at 90% of current levels until Sept. 30.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So they want the money, but they don't want to, like, play by the rules? They can't cut jobs when they're making stuff no one wants? That's, uh, that's just wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they want the money, but they don't want to, like, play by the rules? They can't cut jobs when they're making stuff no one wants? That's, uh, that's just wild.

dialogue_turns.text: It's a dilemma, for sure. Richard Aboulafia called it "pulling demand forward to a certain extent," but it "probably beats falling off a cliff."
